To clarify I’m having trouble understanding how to program it.

posts.cooked:
This was a big teaching point for me and my team this year.  There are a number of excellent resources out there.  The WPILIB link above has some great tools for learning how to tune things. I can’t recommend them enough.

One thing that’s been useful is this youtube link - I don’t know where I originally found it - but I find it does a great job of explaining things without any worlds whatsoever PID demo (youtube.com)

It take a little practice to get the hang of, and there’s a bit of art to it. We tend to looks at the values this way.  The goal is to get a motor to reach a particular setpoint (or speed). Generally we tend to zero all the values and approach things in this order.

P(Proportional value) - Manipulate this one first. You want the motor to reach it’s setpoint and oscillate a bit. You can then back off of P.

I - Integral - This is error correction. If your motor isn’t quite reaching it’s setpoint add I

D- Derivative - This provides dampening to prevent you from overshooting. This will slow down the motor as it approaches it’s setpoint.

Note 0 - The WPILIB link above and it’s javascript tutorials are FANTASTIC. These really helped us.

Note 1 - There is often more than one solution to this problem. It’s really about finding something that works for you.

Note 2- With your robot its possible to use the REV client and Phoenix Tuner to pinpoint these values quickly.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I’m not sure if you wanted to understand and program your own PID controller or if you wanted to know how to use preprogrammed controllers say from WPILib, Rev, or CTRE .

For the math details I suggest also looking at the source code for the WPILib PIDController .

To use the controllers look at others’ code as suggested and you can take a look at my command-based examples in GitHub - tom131313/Example-LED specifically RobotContainer has a Xbox trigger axis binding for the AchieveHueGoal WPILib PIDController.

You can run the example project in simulation mode and see the fake LED output which for the AchieveHueGoal example shows the progress of going around the color wheel from 0 to the desired setpoint from the Xbox. Play with kP to see how you converge to the setpoint.

Oblarg posted this code here on CD that I use as a model to use WPILib PIDController:

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: If you have access to falcon or kraken motors, I’d highly recommend running the pid on the talonFX motor controller. If you want implementation details, I can explain more, but the reasoning is that it gives you really easy access to motion profiling, which gives you more predictable mechanism movement, and it also runs the loop at 1000 times per second, instead of the default wpilib 50 times per second.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
Oliver_stivers:

it also runs the loop at 1000 times per second, instead of the default wpilib 50 times per second

To be clear, the main reason to use on-motor-controller feedback is the determinism it offers over a Java robot program. Java’s garbage collector interrupts all the time and can cause random spikes in control loop timing. 1 kHz feedback is a marketing meme because no FRC mechanisms need it. The hardest thing I’ve had to control was a really light shooter flywheel in 2020, and even that did fine with 200 Hz (we used real-time C++ for deterministic scheduling). Every other mechanism can be controlled at 100 Hz or lower.

The less the mechanism accelerates in one timestep, the slower you can update the control input. At higher update rates, you’re better approximating a continuous control system, which just means there’s no delay between control input updates; the system dynamics are still there.

You can also run WPILib controllers at faster rates by overriding TimedRobot’s loop rate via super(dt) or calling TimedRobot.addPeriodic() . Scheduling Functions at Custom Frequencies — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation . Given the limitations of Java, I’d recommend staying at or below 100 Hz.

Since I haven’t seen any recent, basic WPILib motion profile + feedforward + feedback examples around, here’s one in Java and C++:

I’m aware basically no one writes code like this anymore now that everything’s vendor-specific, but still, you can do a lot with a little and without installing additional software.

posts.cooked: We usually use the highly scientific method of an educated guess and check.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
scimn27:

an educated guess and check.

Exponential Search FTW in these cases.

If it ain’t doin enough, double it.

If it’s doin too much, cut it half.

The main motivation for the interactive tutorials is to teach what too-much and ain’t-enough look like in different situations.
Yes…. But…. I prefer to call it empirical research.  As a mentor it really helps my credibility.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: My method is to imagine the closest point I would feel safe for the device to be traveling full velocity and calculate a P value for that, make it about .75 that value and then try it out.  Increase as needed.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
One thing I’ve not seen discussed yet in this thread is feed forward.  Feed forward is a modeled term that estimates the motor output required based solely on the setpoint (not on the current position, which is what PID does as a feed back calculation).

The idea is the feed forward gets you as close as possible, and then the PID is only correcting for residual error (things which can’t be well modeled, like friction, or unknowable external loads).  This reduces the amount of tuning required and is more well behaved in general for systems that can be reasonably modeled with feed forward.

For an example of doing this with an arm, with comparisons of pure feedforward, pure feedback, and a combination of the two:

In this section, we will tune a simple position controller for a vertical arm. The same tuning principles explained below will work also for almost all position-control scenarios under the load of ...
